measured_by: Empathic Concern subscale of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI)
justification: "...participants scoring high on dispositional empathic concern (EC, assessed with Interpersonal Reactivity Index or IRI) judged accidental harms to be less morally permissible…"
"In Study 2, we replicated this effect using another measure of trait empathy (Empathy index) and found a positive association…"

"In Study 3, we borrowed a recently developed measure designed to dissociate empathy from compassion and found that there was a positive correlation between empathy scores and severity of judgments for accidents…"
"In Study 4, we found that trial-by-trial ratings of perceived victim suffering for each moral vignette predicted harsher moral condemnation…"

measured_by: fMRI activation in the ‘empathy network’ localized with painful-video task
justification: "To localize the empathy network in each participant, we used a modified version of a prior task… watching painful videos reliably activated bilateral insula, ACC, and MCC—regions we treat as an empathy network."

measured_by: 7-point Likert question: “How morally acceptable was [the agent]’s behavior?”
justification: "After reading each story, participants provided two types of moral judgments… acceptability—‘How morally acceptable was [the agent]’s behavior?’ (1: Totally acceptable to 7: Not at all acceptable)…"

measured_by: 7-point Likert question: “How much blame does [the agent] deserve?”
justification: "…blame—‘How much blame does [the agent] deserve?’ (1: Not at all to 7: Very much)."
The authors note that earlier online studies "included the terms 'wrongness' and 'punishment'" and measured wrongness judgments with a rating scale comparable to the later acceptability scale.

measured_by: Punishment judgment scale (rating magnitude of deserved punishment)
justification: The mixed-design behavioral studies (6-7) contrasted "punishment versus wrongness judgments", indicating that punishment was operationalized with its own quantitative rating scale.
